title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Learning Objectives
After this session, you will be able to:

Identify the fundamental elements of a process-control loop.
Draw and interpret standard process-control block diagrams.
Distinguish between controlled and manipulated variables.
Evaluate system performance based on stability, steady-state, and transient criteria.


Welcome students to the first module of Instrumentation. We are transitioning from simple measurement to active control. Our goal today is to define what ‘control’ means in an industrial context and how we represent these systems mathematically and visually.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
What is Control?
Control refers to methods used to force parameters in an environment to have specific values.


Natural Control
Biological functions like:

Body temperature regulation.
Fluid flow in organisms.
Glucose levels.


Artificial Control
Engineering solutions like:

Room temperature (\(21^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)).
IC Manufacturing.
Spacecraft navigation.



Control isn’t just an engineering concept; it’s a fundamental principle of life (Homeostasis). In ECE, we take these logical strategies and implement them using hardware and software.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Process Principles: Self-Regulation
A process is Self-Regulating if the variable adopts a stable value for a given input without external intervention.

Example: A tank where \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}\).
As height \(h\) increases, \(Q_{\mathrm{out}}\) increases.
Eventually, \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} = Q_{\mathrm{in}}\) and the level stabilizes.







Important


Self-regulation does not provide regulation to a specific setpoint; it simply finds an equilibrium.




Self-regulation is the “natural” state of the system. In the tank example, if you increase the input flow, the level will find a new equilibrium, but it won’t return to the original level unless we add a control loop.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Interactive: Finding Equilibrium
Calculate the stabilized height (\(h\)) based on the self-regulation formula: \(h = (Q_{\mathrm{out}} / K)^2\).
Try changing the Input Flow (\(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\)) below:







In Example 1 of the text, we see that for a flow of 2 gal/min and a K of 1.156, the level stabilizes at 3 feet. If the user changes Q_in to 4, the height will quadrupal to 12 feet.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
The Evolution of Control


Human-Aided

Sensor: Human eye (sight tube).
Controller: Human brain (decision).
Actuator: Human hand (turning valve).


Automatic

Sensor: Electronic transducer.
Controller: Microprocessor/PLC.
Actuator: Motorized/Pneumatic valve.



The logic remains identical between human-aided and automatic control. We are simply replacing the biological components with faster, more reliable mechanical and electronic counterparts.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Types of Control Systems








Type
Objective
Example




Process Control
Regulate a variable to a constant setpoint.
Temperature in a chemical vat.


Servomechanism
Force a variable to track a moving reference.
Robot arm following a path.


Discrete-State
Manage a sequence of start/stop events.
Paint mixing schedule (PLCs).




Distinguish these clearly: Process control wants things to stay the same (regulation). Servos want things to follow a specific movement (tracking). Discrete-state is binary (on/off logic).

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
The Process-Control Block Diagram
All automated loops can be broken down into these functional elements:












This is the “Universal Language” of control. Every component we study this semester fits into one of these blocks. Note the Feedback loop—the information ‘feeds back’ to the start to correct the error.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Key Definitions

Controlled Variable (\(c\)): The specific parameter we wish to maintain (e.g., Temperature, Level).
Manipulated Variable (\(u\)): The parameter we change to affect the process (e.g., Valve position, Heater voltage).
Sensor: Converts the controlled variable into an analog signal (voltage, current).
Error Detector: Determines \(e = r - b\).







Sensor vs. Transducer


All sensors are transducers (converting energy), but not all transducers are sensors (e.g., an I/P converter converts current to pressure but doesn’t measure the process).

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Physical vs. Functional Mapping
In ECE, we map physical hardware to the functional blocks:







G

Physical Hardware

The DOT diagram shows how we abstract the real world. A “Pneumatic Valve” is physically a piece of iron and air lines, but functionally it is the “Final Control Element.”

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Evaluation: The 3 Pillars of Performance
How do we know if our control system is “good”?

Stability: The system must not oscillate out of control or diverge.
Steady-State Regulation: The error should be minimized during normal operation (within allowable \(\pm \Delta c\)).
Transient Regulation: How the system handles sudden changes (setpoint shifts or disturbances).


Stability is non-negotiable. Steady-state is about accuracy over time. Transient is about speed and “smoothness” during changes.

title: Introduction to Process Control
Introduction to Process Control
text:
Standard Tuning Criteria
When a system is cyclic, we use two primary metrics:


1. Minimum Area
Adjusts tuning so the total integral of the absolute error is minimized: \[A = \int |e(t)| dt\]

2. Quarter Amplitude
Specifies that each successive peak is 1/4 the height of the previous peak: \[a_{n+1} = \frac{a_n}{4}\]


Quarter amplitude is a classic “rule of thumb” in industrial tuning. It provides a good balance between fast response and stability.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Summary

Process Control is about maintaining a variable at a setpoint via a feedback loop.
The Loop consists of: Process \(\rightarrow\) Sensor \(\rightarrow\) Error Detector \(\rightarrow\) Controller \(\rightarrow\) Actuator.
Evaluation is based on how quickly and accurately the system reaches the setpoint without becoming unstable.


Final wrap-up. Remind students that the block diagram is the foundation for everything else in the course.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Problem 1: Self-Regulation Calculation
A self-regulating water tank has a flow-to-level relationship defined by: \[Q_{\mathrm{out}} = K\sqrt{h}\]
Given:

The constant \(K = 0.85 \text{ (gal/min)}/\text{ft}^{1/2}\)
The input flow rate \(Q_{\mathrm{in}}\) is maintained at \(2.5 \text{ gal/min}\).

Task:
Calculate the height \(h\) at which the tank level will stabilize.

This problem tests the student’s understanding of self-regulation equilibrium. At equilibrium, the output flow must exactly match the input flow.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Solution 1: Equilibrium Analysis
To find the stabilized height, we set \(Q_{\mathrm{out}} = Q_{\mathrm{in}}\):
\[2.5 = 0.85\sqrt{h}\]
Step 1: Isolate the square root \[\sqrt{h} = \frac{2.5}{0.85}\]
Step 2: Square both sides \[h = \left(\frac{2.5}{0.85}\right)^2\]
Try it yourself with the solver below:







Explain that if \(Q_{in}\) increases, the level \(h\) must rise to increase the “pressure” (head) driving \(Q_{out}\) until they match again. This is the essence of self-regulation.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Problem 2: System Identification
Consider the Automatic Flow Control System described in the text (Figure 6). A system uses an orifice plate to measure flow, a P/I converter, a digital controller, and an I/P converter driving a pneumatic valve.
Match the physical component to its functional block:

Orifice Plate + P/I Converter
Digital Microprocessor
Pneumatic Valve
The Fluid in the Pipe


This problem bridges the gap between physical hardware and the abstract block diagrams used in engineering analysis.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Solution 2: Mapping the Loop
The components map to the standard block diagram as follows:












Emphasize that the I/P converter and the Valve together form the “Final Control Element.” The Orifice plate is the sensor, and the P/I converter provides signal conditioning.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Problem 3: Performance Evaluation
A process engineer is tuning a temperature controller using the Quarter-Amplitude Criterion.
The system suffers a transient disturbance. The first overshoot peak (\(a_1\)) is measured at \(8.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) above the setpoint.
Tasks:

Calculate the required amplitude of the second peak (\(a_2\)).
Calculate the required amplitude of the third peak (\(a_3\)).
If the second peak is actually measured at \(3.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), is the system overdamped or underdamped relative to the criterion?


Quarter-amplitude is a specific ratio (4:1) between successive peaks. This problem requires basic geometric sequence calculation and qualitative comparison.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Solution 3: Tuning Criteria
1. Calculate Second Peak (\(a_2\)): \[a_2 = \frac{a_1}{4} = \frac{8.0}{4} = 2.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\]
2. Calculate Third Peak (\(a_3\)): \[a_3 = \frac{a_2}{4} = \frac{2.0}{4} = 0.5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\]
3. Comparison:

The target \(a_2\) was \(2.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).
The actual \(a_2\) was \(3.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).
Since \(3.0 > 2.0\), the oscillations are decaying slower than the quarter-amplitude target. The system is “less damped” than desired.


Remind students that “Minimum Area” is another criterion. In this case, the actual response has a larger area under the curve than the quarter-amplitude target, making it less ideal by both standards.

title: Introduction to Process Control
text:
Interactive Review: Quarter-Amplitude
Use the slider to set the initial peak (\(a_1\)) and see the target decay sequence.

viewof a1 = Inputs.range([1, 20], {value: 8, step: 0.5, label: "Initial Peak (a1)"});













The interactive solver helps students internalize the 4:1 ratio. Note how quickly the signal must reach zero to satisfy this industrial standard.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Instructional Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:

Distinguish between analog and digital data representation.
Define the roles of ADC and DAC in a control loop.
Explain Supervisory Control vs. Direct Digital Control (DDC).
Describe the concept of Smart Sensors and Process-Control Networks (Fieldbus).
Identify the function of Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs).


We are moving from the general block diagram to the specific “brains” of the system. In modern ECE, the shift from analog circuits to digital microprocessors has changed how we think about precision and networking.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Data Representation: Two Worlds


Analog Data

Continuous: Smooth variation.
Resolution: Theoretically infinite.
Example: A voltage that follows temperature exactly.
Issue: Prone to noise and nonlinearities.


Digital Data

Discrete: Represented by bits (0s and 1s).
Resolution: Limited by the number of bits.
Example: A 4-bit number representing 0–15V.
Advantage: Robust, programmable, and easy to network.



Analog is how the world works; Digital is how computers think. The transition between these two involves a trade-off: we gain programmability but lose the perfectly “smooth” nature of the signal.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Interactive: Understanding Quantization
A 4-bit digital system only has 16 possible levels (\(2^4\)). If we represent 0–15V, it can only resolve steps of 1V. Adjust the “Bits” slider to see how resolution improves.

viewof bits = Inputs.range([2, 10], {value: 4, step: 1, label: "ADC Resolution (Bits)"});













This visualization shows why ECE engineers care about bit-depth. At 2 bits, the signal is a square wave. At 8 or 10 bits, the “stairs” become so small they look smooth to the human eye, but the error (Quantization Error) still exists mathematically.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
The Conversion Bridge
To bridge the gap between the physical process (Analog) and the computer (Digital), we use converters.

ADC (Analog-to-Digital): Converts sensor voltage to binary numbers.
DAC (Digital-to-Analog): Converts computer commands back to a control voltage.







Hexadecimal Representation


Binary is hard for humans. We use Hexadecimal (Hex) as a compact shorthand:
1010 (Binary) = Ah (Hex) = 10 (Decimal).




Table 1 in your text shows the 4-bit mapping. Remember: \(2^n\) gives the number of states. An 8-bit ADC has 256 states, a 12-bit has 4096. Higher bits = Higher precision.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
ON/OFF Control (Discrete)
The simplest digital control: The final element is either ON (1) or OFF (0).

Behavior: The variable oscillates around the setpoint.
Deadband: A range where no action occurs to prevent “chattering” (constant rapid switching).
Hysteresis: Different behavior depending on whether the value is rising or falling.







Tip


Common examples: Your home AC unit, water heater, or a simple thermostat.




ON/OFF is technically a 1-bit digital system. It’s inexpensive but results in constant cycling of the controlled variable.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Analog Control Systems
In a true analog loop, every signal is continuous.












No software involved.
Controlled via Operational Amplifiers (Op-Amps) and components.
Faster than many digital systems, but difficult to “reprogram” without changing hardware.


Before the 1970s, almost all industrial control was analog. If you wanted to change the control logic, you had to get a soldering iron out.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Supervisory Control
When computers were unreliable, they were used for Supervision, not direct action.

The Analog Loop handles the second-by-second control.
The Computer monitors the loop and updates the Setpoint.
Benefit: If the computer crashes, the analog loop keeps running at the last known safe setpoint.


Think of the computer as the “Manager” and the analog loop as the “Worker.” The manager gives orders (setpoints), but the worker does the actual heavy lifting.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Direct Digital Control (DDC)
In DDC, the computer is the controller.












Software performs error detection and control logic.
Flexibility: Change the control algorithm by simply updating code.
Miniaturization: Leads to “Smart Sensors” where all these blocks fit in one tiny housing.


This is the modern standard. Everything from a car engine to a nuclear reactor now uses some form of DDC.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Networked Control & Fieldbus
Modern plants connect hundreds of DDC loops via a Local Area Network (LAN) or Fieldbus.







G



Bus
Fieldbus / LAN Serial Line



PC_Master

Master Controller



PC_Master--Bus




Eng_Station

Engineering Station



Eng_Station--Bus




DDC1

Loop 1: Temp



DDC1--Bus




DDC2

Loop 2: Flow



DDC2--Bus




DDC3

Loop 3: Pressure



DDC3--Bus










Standards: Foundation Fieldbus (US) and Profibus (Europe).
Advantage: “Plug and Play” interoperability between different manufacturers.


Fieldbus allows for distributed control. Instead of thousands of wires running back to a central room, we have one digital cable that “talks” to every device.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs)
PLCs are specialized computers for industrial environments.

Origin: Replaced “Relay Logic” (complex wiring).
Capability: Primarily discrete (ON/OFF) but modern PLCs handle complex DDC.
Inputs: Thermal limit switches, push buttons, proximity sensors.
Outputs: Motor starters, solenoid valves, indicator lights.


If you go into industrial automation, the PLC will be your primary tool. They are designed to be rugged, surviving heat, dust, and electrical noise that would kill a standard office PC.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Summary and Review

Analog is continuous; Digital is discrete/binary.
ADC and DAC are essential interface components for DDC.
Supervisory Control sets the goals; DDC takes the actions.
Fieldbus is the “Ethernet” of the factory floor, allowing devices to talk.
PLCs are the rugged workhorses of discrete-state industrial control.


This concludes the introduction. In the next chapter, we will look at the mathematical transfer functions of these individual blocks.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Problem 1: ADC Resolution
A temperature sensor outputs a voltage from 0 to 15 V. You are using a 4-bit ADC to represent this data (as shown in Table 1 of the text).

What is the voltage resolution (the smallest change in voltage that can be detected)?
If the sensor outputs 6.4 V, what is the 4-bit binary representation?
If the sensor outputs 6.8 V, what is the 4-bit binary representation?


Ask the students to recall the relationship between the number of bits and the number of discrete states. A 4-bit system has \(2^4 = 16\) states.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Solution 1: Resolution & Quantization
1. Voltage Resolution:
The range is 0 to 15 V. With 4 bits, there are \(2^4 = 16\) states (0 to 15). \[\text{Resolution} = \frac{V_{max}}{2^n - 1} = \frac{15\text{ V}}{15} = 1\text{ V/step}\]
2. & 3. Representation for 6.4 V and 6.8 V:
Since the system can only change at 1.0 V increments:

6.4 V is truncated/rounded to the nearest lower integer (in this specific encoding): 6V \(\rightarrow\) 0110₂ (6h).
6.8 V is still represented as 6V \(\rightarrow\) 0110₂ (6h) because it hasn’t reached the 7.0 V threshold.







Quantization Error


The difference between the actual 6.8 V and the represented 6.0 V is the quantization error.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Interactive: 4-Bit ADC Simulator
Use the slider to set an analog voltage. The Python code will simulate the 4-bit ADC logic from the textbook and output the Binary and Hex values.

viewof input_v = Inputs.range([0, 15], {value: 4.5, step: 0.1, label: "Analog Voltage (V)"});













Notice how the output stays the same until you cross the next whole integer boundary. This visualizes the “loss of information” mentioned in the text.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Problem 2: Control Architecture Identification
Match the following scenarios to the correct control type:
A. Supervisory Control
B. Direct Digital Control (DDC)
C. ON/OFF Control

A computer reads a temperature and sends a signal directly to a DAC to adjust a heater’s variable voltage.
An analog loop regulates a valve, but a central computer sends a new setpoint every hour to optimize efficiency.
A relay snaps shut when a tank is empty and opens when it is full.


Encourage students to look for where the “decision” is made and whether the control is continuous or discrete.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Solution 2: Identifying Systems

B. Direct Digital Control (DDC): The computer performs the controller functions (error detection and logic) and talks directly to the final element via a DAC.
A. Supervisory Control: The “heavy lifting” is done by analog loops. The computer only “supervises” by adjusting setpoints.
C. ON/OFF Control: This is a discrete-state system where the controller output is binary (Open/Closed).

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Problem 3: The DDC Loop Diagram
Task: Draw a block diagram for a Direct Digital Control (DDC) system for a flow process.
Identify where these signals live:

\(N_T\) (Digital representation of measurement)
\(V_Q\) (Analog control signal)
\(N_Q\) (Digital control command)


Students often confuse the placement of ADC and DAC. Remember: ADC follows the sensor; DAC precedes the actuator.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Solution 3: DDC Block Diagram












ADC: Converts the physical world into bits for the computer.
Computer: Calculates the error and determines the required action in software.
DAC: Converts the software’s decision back into a physical voltage/current.


In a Smart Sensor, all the components inside the orange and blue boxes might be integrated into a single physical housing.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Final Challenge: Design Logic
You are designing a Fieldbus network for a factory. You have a “Smart Sensor” and a “Programmable Logic Controller (PLC)”.
Question: Why is a Fieldbus better than running individual analog wires (4-20mA) from every sensor to the control room?

Think about cost, noise, and the “Plug and Play” concept mentioned in the text.

title: Analog and Digital Control Systems
text:
Solution: The Network Advantage

Reduced Wiring: A single serial cable (the bus) replaces hundreds of individual wire pairs.
Interoperability: Standards like Profibus or Fieldbus allow equipment from different vendors to work together (“Plug and Play”).
Data Integrity: Digital signals on a bus are less susceptible to the voltage drops and noise that affect analog 4-20mA lines over long distances.
Diagnostics: Smart sensors can send calibration data and error codes over the network, which a simple analog signal cannot do.


This wraps up our practice. These concepts of digital conversion and networking form the backbone of modern Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT).

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Instructional Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:

Define accuracy, hysteresis, resolution, and sensitivity.
List SI units for length, time, mass, and electric current.
Convert between SI, English, and standard analog signal ranges.
Recognize common P&ID symbols and line types used in industry.


Standardization is the bedrock of engineering. Without a common set of units and symbols, we couldn’t communicate complex plant designs. Today we define the “rules of the game” for measurement and documentation.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
The International System (SI)
As ECE students, we prioritize SI units, but you must remain fluent in English units for industrial legacy systems.



Quantity
Unit
Symbol




Length
Meter
m


Mass
Kilogram
kg


Time
Second
s


Electric current
Ampere
A


Temperature
Kelvin
K









Derived Units



Force: Newton (N) \(= 1 \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m/s^2}\)
Energy: Joule (J) \(= 1 \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m^2/s^2}\)





Note that the Kelvin is the base unit for temperature, but Celsius is common in the field. Also, we often deal with very small currents (mA) or very large pressures, making metric prefixes (milli, micro, kilo, mega) essential.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Interactive: Unit Conversion Lab
Practice converting values between systems. Example: Convert mass (lb to kg) or pressure (dyne/cm² to Pa).







Example 5 in the text shows a 2-lb object is ~0.908 kg. In instrumentation, you’ll often see pressure sensors rated in PSI while the controller math expects Pascals.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Standard Analog Signals
Information is transmitted across plants using two primary standards:


1. Electric Current
Range: 4 to 20 mA

Why? Immune to line resistance (noise).
Live Zero: 4mA indicates 0% signal. 0mA indicates a broken wire (fault).


2. Pneumatic Pressure
Range: 3 to 15 psi

Why? Safe in explosive environments (no sparks).
SI Equivalent: 20 to 100 kPa.



The “Live Zero” (4mA) is a brilliant engineering feature. If a wire snaps, the current drops to 0mA, which the controller recognizes immediately as a “Fault” rather than a “Zero measurement.”

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Interactive: Signal Mapping
In Example 7, we map a Temperature Range (\(20^{\circ}\) to \(120^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)) to (\(4\) to \(20\mathrm{mA}\)).
Input a temperature to see the resulting current:

viewof temp_input = Inputs.range([20, 120], {value: 66, step: 1, label: "Temp (°C)"});













The formula \(I = mT + I_0\) is a standard linear transformation. For ECEs, this is just \(y = mx + b\). You’ll do this calculation thousands of times in your career to calibrate sensors.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Performance Definitions

Transfer Function: The relationship between input \(x(t)\) and output \(y(t)\).
Accuracy: The maximum error (usually \(\pm\) % of Full Scale or Span).
Sensitivity: The ratio of output change to input change (e.g., \(5\mathrm{mV} / {}^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)).
Resolution: The smallest measurable change in the input variable.







System Accuracy


When multiple blocks are in series, uncertainties add up!
Worst Case: \(\frac{\Delta V}{V} = \pm \frac{\Delta K}{K} \pm \frac{\Delta G}{G}\)
Realistic (RMS): \(\sqrt{(\frac{\Delta K}{K})^2 + (\frac{\Delta G}{G})^2}\)




Accuracy can be sneaky. % of Full Scale is very different from % of Reading. If you have a 100V meter with 1% FS accuracy, your error is ±1V whether you are measuring 100V or 2V. At 2V, that’s a 50% relative error!

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Hysteresis: The Memory Effect
Hysteresis is a predictable error where the output depends on the history of the input (whether it is increasing or decreasing).







Hysteresis is common in mechanical systems (like gear backlash) or magnetic materials. If you always approach your setpoint from the same direction, you can negate this error.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
P&ID: The Engineer’s Blueprint
P&ID (Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams) use symbols defined by ANSI/ISA S5.1.
Line Types

Heavy Solid: Main product flow.
Dashed (—): Electric signal (4-20mA).
Hatched (///): Pneumatic signal (3-15 psi).
Bubbled (-o-): Digital data link.


Imagine walking into a massive refinery. You can’t see through the steel pipes. The P&ID is your map; it tells you exactly where the sensors are and how the data flows.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
P&ID Instrument Bubbles
Instruments are drawn as “bubbles” with letter codes:



First Letter (Variable)
Succeeding (Function)




T (Temperature)
C (Controller)


P (Pressure)
T (Transmitter)


L (Level)
V (Valve)


F (Flow)
I (Indicator)



Example: TIC 101 = Temperature Indicating Controller, Loop 101.

If the bubble has a line through it, it’s located in the central control room. If it’s empty, it’s out “in the field” (on the factory floor).

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Case Study: Analyzing a Loop
Consider a reaction vessel with a temperature loop:












TT 301 measures and transmits.
TC 301 decides the action.
PY 301 converts the electronic signal to air pressure.
TV 301 (Final Control Element) physically changes the process.


Notice the “PY” designation. It stands for Pressure (P) and a relay/conversion function (Y). It’s the bridge between the electronic world of the controller and the pneumatic world of the valve actuator.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Summary and Key Takeaways

Units: SI is standard, but English units (PSI, lb) persist in industry.
Signals: 4-20mA is the electronic standard; 3-15 psi is the pneumatic standard.
Error: Accuracy is often defined by Span or Full Scale.
Hysteresis: approach direction matters.
P&ID: Use the ANSI/ISA shorthand to map your systems.







Practice


Try to identify the controlled and manipulated variables in every P&ID you see!




This concludes our introduction to the terminology and standards of process control. In the next chapter, we will begin looking at the physics of individual sensors.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Problem 1: Unit Conversion (Pressure)
The Challenge:
An industrial boiler’s safety valve is rated for a maximum pressure of 250 psi. To calibrate the electronic pressure transmitter (which uses SI units), you must convert this value to Pascals (Pa) and MegaPascals (MPa).
Given:

\(1 \text{ psi} = 6,894.76 \text{ Pa}\)







Recall


\(1 \text{ MPa} = 10^6 \text{ Pa}\).




Converting PSI to Pa/MPa is a daily task in global engineering firms where US-made hardware meets European-standard software.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Solution 1: Pressure Conversion
Step 1: Convert to Pa
\[P = 250 \text{ psi} \times 6,894.76 \frac{\text{Pa}}{\text{psi}} = 1,723,690 \text{ Pa}\]
Step 2: Convert to MPa
\[P = \frac{1,723,690 \text{ Pa}}{10^6} = 1.72 \text{ MPa}\]
Result: The safety limit is 1.72 MPa.

Encourage students to use scientific notation for very large numbers to avoid transcription errors.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Problem 2: Signal Mapping (4-20 mA)
The Challenge:
A level sensor measures a tank height from 0.0 to 5.0 meters. This measurement is converted into a 4 to 20 mA current signal.

Find the linear equation \(I = f(h)\) relating current (\(I\)) to height (\(h\)).
Calculate the current produced when the tank height is 3.2 meters.


Mapping a physical range to an electrical range is the core of “Signal Conditioning.” This is a linear \(y = mx + b\) problem.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Interactive Solution 2: Mapping Tool
Use the calculator below to verify the mapping logic.
The formula used: \(I = \frac{16}{h_{max}} \times h + 4\)






Manual Check:
\(I = (3.2 \times 3.2) + 4 = 10.24 + 4 = \mathbf{14.24 \text{ mA}}\)

Show students how the “Live Zero” (the +4) ensures that even at 0 meters, we have current flowing.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Problem 3: Understanding Accuracy
The Challenge:
A pressure gauge has a range of 50 to 150 psi. A reading of 85 psi is observed. Calculate the uncertainty (error) in psi if the accuracy is specified as:

\(\pm 1\%\) of Full Scale (FS).
\(\pm 1\%\) of Span.
\(\pm 1\%\) of Reading.


This problem highlights why “Accuracy” is a tricky term. The same 1% means different things depending on the reference.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Solution 3: Accuracy Comparison

a) Full Scale (FS): Highest value is 150 psi. \(\text{Error} = \pm 0.01 \times 150 = \mathbf{\pm 1.5 \text{ psi}}\)
b) Span: (Max - Min) = \(150 - 50 = 100 \text{ psi}\). \(\text{Error} = \pm 0.01 \times 100 = \mathbf{\pm 1.0 \text{ psi}}\)
c) Reading: Current measurement is 85 psi. \(\text{Error} = \pm 0.01 \times 85 = \mathbf{\pm 0.85 \text{ psi}}\)







Important


Note that Span accuracy is tighter than Full Scale accuracy in this specific case.




Ask students: “Which specification would a salesperson prefer to use to make their device look better?” Usually, they use % of Reading if they can, as it sounds more precise.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Problem 4: System Accuracy (RMS)
The Challenge:
A measurement loop consists of two blocks in series:

Transducer: Accuracy \(\pm 2.0\%\)
Signal Conditioner: Accuracy \(\pm 0.8\%\)

Calculate the Worst-Case system accuracy and the RMS (statistically likely) system accuracy.

Errors compound. If the sensor is off and the conditioner is also off in the same direction, we get the worst case. If they are random, they might partially cancel out (RMS).

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Problem 5: Resolution and Linearity
The Challenge:
A digital temperature sensor uses an 8-bit ADC to cover a range of \(0^{\circ}\) to \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

What is the Resolution of this sensor in degrees Celsius?
If the sensor has a Linearity of 0.5% FS, what is the maximum deviation in degrees?


Resolution is about the “stairs” (discrete steps). Linearity is about how far the “stairs” deviate from a straight line.

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Solution 5: Resolution and Linearity
1. Resolution:
An 8-bit ADC has \(2^8 = 256\) states.
\[\text{Resolution} = \frac{\text{Range}}{\text{States}} = \frac{100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}}{256} \approx \mathbf{0.39^{\circ}\mathrm{C} \text{ per bit}}\]
2. Linearity:
\(0.5\%\) of Full Scale (\(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)): \[\text{Deviation} = 0.005 \times 100 = \mathbf{\pm 0.5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}}\]






Note


In this system, the linearity error (\(0.5^{\circ}\)) is actually larger than the resolution step (\(0.39^{\circ}\))!




This is a common realization: just because you have high resolution (lots of bits) doesn’t mean you have high accuracy (linearity).

title: Units, Standards, and Definitions
text:
Summary of Key Formulae







Concept
Formula




Signal Mapping
\(y = \left(\frac{y_{max} - y_{min}}{x_{max} - x_{min}}\right)(x - x_{min}) + y_{min}\)


Span
\(\text{Span} = \text{Range}_{max} - \text{Range}_{min}\)


Worst-Case Accuracy
\(A_{total} = A_1 + A_2 + ... + A_n\)


RMS Accuracy
\(A_{rms} = \sqrt{A_1^2 + A_2^2 + ... + A_n^2}\)


Digital Resolution
\(\text{Res} = \frac{\text{Full Scale Range}}{2^n}\)




Encourage students to keep these formulas in their reference sheets for the upcoming lab and exams.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Instructional Objectives
The purpose of this presentation is to introduce analog signal-conditioning methods used in process-control systems.

Define the principles of analog signal conditioning.
Analyze the impact of loading on measurement accuracy.
Evaluate passive circuits (dividers, bridges, and filters).
Design simple RC filters for noise reduction.


Welcome to the lecture on Analog Signal Conditioning. In process control, sensors rarely provide a signal that can be plugged directly into a controller or computer. Today, we will focus on how we transform those raw sensor signals using passive components like resistors and capacitors to make them usable.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
What is Signal Conditioning?
Signal conditioning refers to operations performed on signals to convert them into a form suitable for interfacing with other elements in a process-control loop.

Conditioned Output: Remains an analog representation of the variable.
Interface Requirement: Crucial before Analog-to-Digital Conversion (ADC).
Transfer Function: The mathematical relationship between input and output.

Example: A voltage amplifier has a transfer function \(V_{out} = G \cdot V_{in}\).



Even in a digital world, the “front end” is almost always analog. We use the term ‘Transfer Function’ to describe how the circuit alters the signal. If we have a sensor outputting 0.2V and we need 5V, our conditioning circuit must have a specific gain and bias.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Common Operations


1. Level & Bias Changes
Adjusting the magnitude (gain) and zero-value (offset).

Amplification: Gain \(> 1\)
Attenuation: Gain \(< 1\)

2. Linearization
Converting nonlinear sensor outputs (like CdS cells) into linear representations via circuits or software.

3. Conversions

Resistance to Voltage: Bridges.
Voltage to Current: 4-20 mA standards for transmission.

4. Filtering & Matching

Filtering: Removing 60 Hz line noise.
Impedance Matching: Preventing signal loss.



These four pillars define the engineer’s toolkit. Level and bias adjustments are like the ‘zero’ and ‘span’ on an instrument. Conversions are vital because while many sensors change resistance, most controllers expect voltage or current.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
The Concept of Loading
Loading occurs when connecting a measurement circuit to a sensor causes the sensor’s output voltage to drop.
Thévenin’s Theorem Model:
A sensor can be modeled as a voltage source (\(V_x\)) in series with an internal resistance (\(R_x\)).
\[V_y = V_x \left(1 - \frac{R_x}{R_L + R_x}\right)\]
To minimize loading errors, we require \(R_L \gg R_x\).

This is a critical concept for ECE students. If you use a multimeter with low input impedance to measure a high-impedance source, your reading will be wrong. Equation 1 shows that if the load resistance RL is not significantly larger than the source resistance Rx, the measured voltage Vy will be lower than the actual source voltage Vx.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Interactive Loading Simulation
Adjust the Load Resistance (\(R_L\)) to see how it affects the measured voltage.
Sensor: \(V_x = 10V\), \(R_{source} = 5k\Omega\).

viewof rl = Inputs.range([100, 100000], {value: 5000, step: 100, label: "Load Resistance (Ω)"});













In this simulation, watch how the error increases as RL approaches 5000 ohms. When RL equals Rx, the voltage is halved (5V). This demonstrates why high input impedance is a primary requirement for instrumentation amplifiers.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Voltage Divider Circuits
The simplest way to convert resistance change to voltage change.











\[V_D = \frac{R_2 V_s}{R_1 + R_2}\]
Challenges:

Nonlinear: \(V_D\) vs \(R_2\) is not a straight line.
Output Impedance: \(Z_{out} = R_1 \parallel R_2\).
Self-Heating: Current through \(R_2\) may change its temperature.


The voltage divider is common but has flaws. The relationship between R2 and VD is hyperbolic, not linear. Also, the current required to generate a voltage drop might heat up the sensor, leading to measurement errors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Wheatstone Bridge
Used for high-precision measurement of small resistance changes.











Null Condition (\(V_a = V_b\)): \[R_3 R_2 = R_1 R_4\]

The Wheatstone bridge is the gold standard for resistive sensors like strain gauges. Its greatest advantage is that it provides a differential output that is zero when the bridge is balanced. This allows us to amplify only the change in signal.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Bridge Offset Voltage
When the bridge is not balanced, the offset voltage \(\Delta V\) (assuming infinite detector impedance) is:
\[\Delta V = V \left[ \frac{R_3}{R_1 + R_3} - \frac{R_4}{R_2 + R_4} \right]\]

For small changes (\(\Delta R\)), the output is approximately linear.
For large changes, the output becomes significantly nonlinear.


Note the formula. If all resistors are equal, Delta V is zero. As R4 changes slightly, Delta V changes. Engineers must decide if the sensor’s range stays within the ‘approximately linear’ region or if software linearization is needed.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Interactive Wheatstone Bridge
Balance the bridge by adjusting \(R_3\).
Given: \(V = 10V\), \(R_1=100\Omega\), \(R_2=100\Omega\), \(R_4 (Sensor)=120\Omega\).

viewof r3_val = Inputs.range([50, 150], {value: 100, step: 0.1, label: "R3 (Ω)"});













Try to find the null point. You’ll notice that as R3 increases, the offset crosses zero. This balance point is independent of the supply voltage stability, which is why bridges are so stable.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Lead Compensation
In industrial settings, sensors are often far from the bridge circuit. Long wires add resistance that changes with temperature.
Solution: Three-wire connection

Wire 1: In series with \(R_3\).
Wire 2: In series with \(R_4\) (sensor).
Wire 3: Power lead (carries no bridge current).

Since Wire 1 and Wire 2 are identical and experience the same environment, their resistance changes cancel out in the null equation.

This is a classic engineering solution to a “real-world” problem. By placing one lead in each arm of the bridge, the error becomes a “common-mode” signal that the bridge naturally rejects.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Low-Pass and High-Pass Basics
Used to eliminate unwanted noise (like 60 Hz hum or high-frequency transients).
Critical Frequency (\(f_c\)):
The frequency where output power drops by half (\(-3\text{ dB}\)) or voltage drops to \(0.707 V_{in}\).
\[f_c = \frac{1}{2\pi RC}\]

Low-Pass: Passes \(f < f_c\), blocks \(f > f_c\).
High-Pass: Passes \(f > f_c\), blocks \(f < f_c\).


Filters are essential for cleaning up signals. A low-pass filter is like a sponge that soaks up fast jitters while letting the slow, steady signal through. We choose R and C values to set the “cutoff” point where this soaking starts.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Advanced Passive Filtering
Cascaded Filters

Used to increase the “sharpness” of the cutoff.
Loading Warning: The second stage loads the first stage.
Resulting gain is the product of individual gains (if isolated).

Band-Pass Filters

Combination of a High-Pass and a Low-Pass in series.
Defined by a lower cutoff \(f_L\) and higher cutoff \(f_H\).

Notch Filters (Twin-T)

Specifically designed to reject a very narrow range of frequencies (e.g., exactly 60 Hz).


A Twin-T notch filter is particularly useful in medical electronics like ECGs, where the 60Hz power line noise is often much larger than the heart signal itself. However, passive notch filters are sensitive to component tolerances, often requiring precision resistors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Summary & Key Takeaways

Signal Conditioning is the bridge between the raw sensor and the data acquisition system.
Loading is the enemy of accuracy; always ensure \(R_{in} \gg R_{source}\).
Bridges convert resistance to voltage with high precision and provide a differential “zero” reference.
RC Filters are simple but effective tools for noise management, defined by \(f_c = 1/(2\pi RC)\).


To conclude: always look at the impedances before you connect two circuits. In our next session, we will look at how Operational Amplifiers (Op-Amps) can make these conditioning tasks much easier by providing high input impedance and active filtering.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 1: Loading Effects
Scenario:
A temperature sensor has an output resistance of \(5.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\) and a transfer function of \(20 \, \text{mV/}^\circ\text{C}\).
It is connected to an amplifier with an input resistance of \(10 \, \text{k}\Omega\) and a gain of 10.
Task:
Calculate the actual amplifier output voltage when the temperature is \(50^\circ\text{C}\).

Students often calculate the “ideal” value first (1.0V). The key is to realize the sensor acts as a Thévenin source, and the amplifier’s input resistance acts as a load. This demonstrates that \(R_{in}\) must be much larger than \(R_{source}\) to maintain accuracy.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 1: Loading Effects


Step 1: Ideal Sensor Output
\(V_T = (20 \, \text{mV/}^\circ\text{C}) \times 50^\circ\text{C} = 1.0 \, \text{V}\)
Step 2: Loaded Input (\(V_{in}\))
Using the loading formula:
\(V_{in} = V_T \left( \frac{R_L}{R_L + R_x} \right)\)
\(V_{in} = 1.0 \left( \frac{10 \, \text{k}\Omega}{10 \, \text{k}\Omega + 5 \, \text{k}\Omega} \right) = 0.67 \, \text{V}\)

Step 3: Amplifier Output
\(V_{out} = \text{Gain} \times V_{in}\)
\(V_{out} = 10 \times 0.67 \, \text{V} = 6.7 \, \text{V}\)
Conclusion:
Without considering loading, we would have expected \(10 \, \text{V}\).
The error is a staggering 33%.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 2: Voltage Divider Design
Scenario:
A supply voltage \(V_s = 5.0 \, \text{V}\) is connected to a divider where \(R_1 = 10.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\).
\(R_2\) is a sensor that varies from \(4.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\) to \(12.0 \, \text{k}\Omega\).
Task:

Find the range of the output voltage \(V_D\).
Determine the maximum power dissipated by the sensor.


Dividers are the simplest conversion circuits. Note how the output voltage doesn’t change linearly with R2. Power dissipation is critical to avoid “self-heating” errors in thermal sensors.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 2: Voltage Divider
1. Output Voltage Range:

At \(R_2 = 4 \, \text{k}\Omega\): \(V_{D} = \frac{5 \times 4}{10 + 4} = 1.43 \, \text{V}\)
At \(R_2 = 12 \, \text{k}\Omega\): \(V_{D} = \frac{5 \times 12}{10 + 12} = 2.73 \, \text{V}\)

2. Power Dissipation (\(P = V^2 / R\)):

\(P_{min} = \frac{(1.43)^2}{4000} \approx 0.51 \, \text{mW}\)
\(P_{max} = \frac{(2.73)^2}{12000} \approx 0.62 \, \text{mW}\)







Tip


In ECE design, always check if \(0.62 \, \text{mW}\) exceeds the sensor’s power rating to prevent damage or bias.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 3: Bridge Resolution
Scenario:
A Wheatstone bridge has \(R_1 = R_2 = R_3 = R_4 = 120 \, \Omega\) and \(V = 10.0 \, \text{V}\).
A Digital Voltmeter (DVM) with \(100 \, \mu\text{V}\) resolution is used as the detector.
Task:
Find the smallest measurable change in resistance (\(\Delta R_4\)) that the DVM can detect.

Resolution defines the sensitivity of our measurement system. Even if a sensor changes resistance, if the bridge output change is smaller than the DVM resolution, we can’t see it.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 3: Bridge Resolution
The offset voltage is:
\(\Delta V = \frac{V R_3}{R_1 + R_3} - \frac{V (R_4 - \Delta R)}{R_2 + (R_4 - \Delta R)}\)
Given \(\Delta V = 100 \, \mu\text{V}\), \(V = 10 \, \text{V}\), and \(R = 120 \, \Omega\):
\(10^{-4} = \frac{10(120)}{240} - \frac{10(120 - \Delta R)}{120 + (120 - \Delta R)}\)
\(10^{-4} = 5 - \frac{1200 - 10\Delta R}{240 - \Delta R}\)
Solving for \(\Delta R\):
\(\Delta R \approx 0.0048 \, \Omega\)
Result: The bridge can resolve a resistance change as small as \(4.8 \, \text{m}\Omega\).

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 4: AC Bridge Balance
Scenario:
An AC bridge is at null.
\(Z_1 = 1 \, \text{k}\Omega\) (Resistor). \(Z_2 = 2 \, \text{k}\Omega\) (Resistor). \(Z_3 = 1 \, \text{k}\Omega\) resistor in series with a \(1 \, \mu\text{F}\) capacitor.
Task:
Find the equivalent resistance (\(R_x\)) and capacitance (\(C_x\)) for the unknown arm \(Z_x\).

In AC bridges, we must balance both the real (magnitude) and imaginary (phase) parts. The frequency (\(\omega\)) usually cancels out in simple RC bridges, making the balance independent of frequency.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 4: AC Bridge Balance
Null Condition: \(Z_1 Z_x = Z_2 Z_3\)
\(R_1 (R_x - \frac{j}{\omega C_x}) = R_2 (R_3 - \frac{j}{\omega C})\)
Equating Real Parts:
\(R_1 R_x = R_2 R_3 \implies R_x = \frac{R_2 R_3}{R_1} = \frac{(2\text{k})(1\text{k})}{1\text{k}} = 2 \, \text{k}\Omega\)
Equating Imaginary Parts:
\(\frac{R_1}{\omega C_x} = \frac{R_2}{\omega C} \implies C_x = C \frac{R_1}{R_2} = (1 \, \mu\text{F}) \frac{1\text{k}}{2\text{k}} = 0.5 \, \mu\text{F}\)

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 5: Low-Pass Filter Design
Requirement:
A signal contains data at \(f < 1 \, \text{kHz}\) but has noise at \(1 \, \text{MHz}\). Design a filter that attenuates the \(1 \, \text{MHz}\) noise to \(1\%\) of its original amplitude (\(V_{out}/V_{in} = 0.01\)).
Task:

Calculate the required critical frequency \(f_c\).
Select \(R\) and \(C\) values.


Engineers often start with a desired attenuation at a specific noise frequency. Then they work backward to find the cutoff frequency.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 5: Low-Pass Filter
Step 1: Find \(f_c\)
\(\frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + (f/f_c)^2}}\) \(0.01 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + (10^6/f_c)^2}} \implies (10^6/f_c)^2 \approx 10,000\)
\(f_c = 10 \, \text{kHz}\)
Step 2: Component Selection
Pick \(C = 0.01 \, \mu\text{F}\):
\(R = \frac{1}{2 \pi f_c C} = \frac{1}{2 \pi (10^4)(10^{-8})} = 1591 \, \Omega\)
Standard Choice: Use \(R = 1.5 \, \text{k}\Omega\) or a \(1.6 \, \text{k}\Omega\) resistor.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Problem 6: Twin-T Notch Filter
Scenario:
An EKG monitor is picking up \(60 \, \text{Hz}\) interference from power lines.
Design a Twin-T notch filter to reject this specific frequency.
Task:

Find \(f_c\) for the Twin-T circuit.
If \(C = 0.1 \, \mu\text{F}\), find \(R, R_1,\) and \(C_1\).


The Twin-T is a special passive filter. Note that the notch frequency \(f_n\) is NOT equal to \(f_c\). It is \(0.785 \times f_c\). This is a common point of confusion for students.

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Solution 6: Twin-T Notch Filter
Step 1: Calculate \(f_c\)
\(f_n = 0.785 f_c \implies 60 = 0.785 f_c\)
\(f_c = 76.43 \, \text{Hz}\)
Step 2: Calculate Components

\(R = \frac{1}{2 \pi f_c C} = \frac{1}{2 \pi (76.43)(10^{-7})} = 20,823 \, \Omega\)
\(R_1 = \frac{\pi R}{10} = \frac{\pi (20823)}{10} \approx 6,541 \, \Omega\)
\(C_1 = \frac{10 C}{\pi} = \frac{10 (0.1 \, \mu\text{F})}{\pi} \approx 0.318 \, \mu\text{F}\)

title: Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Design your own Bridge
Use the editor below to calculate the bridge offset for your own sensor parameters.
Change r_sensor to see the effect on delta_v.







Encourage students to test “unbalanced” bridges. What happens if R1 is doubled? What happens if the supply voltage drops to 5V? This helps them build intuition for sensitivity and supply dependence.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Describe the ideal op amp model and use the two “golden rules” for circuit analysis.
Analyze and design basic op amp configurations:

Inverting and noninverting amplifiers
Summing amplifiers and voltage followers

Explain nonideal op amp parameters (offsets, slew rate, bandwidth) and when they matter.
Understand and design basic instrumentation circuits:

Differential / instrumentation amplifiers
Voltage‑to‑current and current‑to‑voltage converters

Implement simple integrating and differentiating op amp circuits.
Apply a structured design process to real signal‑conditioning problems.


Explicitly tie each objective to later slides: - Objectives 1–3: Sections 4.1–4.2. - Objective 4: Section 5.4 and example bridge instrumentation. - Objective 5: Sections 5.7–5.9. - Objective 6: Design guideline examples.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Why Op Amps in Instrumentation?

Process control and measurement systems need:

Amplification and attenuation
Impedance matching
Level shifting (offsets)
Filtering and linearization
Voltage ↔︎ current conversion

Historically: built from tubes, then discrete transistors
Today: integrated‑circuit (IC) implementations dominate

Small size
Low power
Low cost
Consistent and well‑documented behavior








Tip


Think of an op amp as a universal analog building block you configure with a few external resistors and capacitors to implement many different transfer functions.




Relate this to typical ECE contexts: sensor interfaces, DAQ boards, motor controllers, biomedical instrumentation. Stress that almost all “analog front ends” hide one or more op amps inside.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: 4.1 Op Amp Characteristics – The Black‑Box View
text:
4.1 Op Amp Characteristics – The Black‑Box View


Symbol



Op amp symbol



Two inputs:

+ noninverting
− inverting

One output
Power pins (\(+V_s\), \(-V_s\)) typically not drawn on signal schematics


Transfer Behavior



Op amp transfer



Output vs. differential input \(V_d = V_2 - V_1\)
Large voltage gain in linear region
Saturates at \(\pm V_{\text{sat}}\) set by supply rails



Clarify the mapping between figure labels and our notation: - In the text, \(V_1\) is on the noninverting terminal (+), \(V_2\) is on the inverting terminal (−). - The differential input \(V_d = V_2 - V_1\). - When \(V_2 > V_1\) (more positive at the inverting input), the output goes negative (−). This inversion behavior is the reason for the input naming.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Op Amp – Key Properties

Infinite open‑loop gain \(A\)

In linear region \(V_{\text{out}} = A \,(V_+ - V_-)\)
Practically \(A \gg 10^5\) even at low frequency

Infinite input impedance

No current flows into \(V_+\) or \(V_-\)

Zero output impedance

Output acts as an ideal voltage source

Infinite bandwidth, zero noise, no offsets (in the ideal model)

These properties lead to two powerful analysis rules when negative feedback is used.






Important


Golden Rules for Ideal Op Amps (with negative feedback):

No current flows into the input terminals: \(I_+ = I_- = 0\).
The inputs are at the same voltage: \(V_+ = V_-\).





Emphasize that these rules are not fundamental device physics; they are approximations that hold because the open‑loop gain is huge and feedback forces the input difference to be near zero. Also highlight: these rules apply only when the op amp is not saturated and there is a feedback path from output to at least one input.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Visualizing Op Amp Saturation












If the differential input is more than a few hundred µV, the output hits \(\pm V_{\text{sat}}\).
Only a very narrow band around \(V_+ \approx V_-\) is linear.


Connect this to comparator behavior: - An op amp with no feedback effectively acts like a comparator: output is either high or low depending on the sign of \(V_+ - V_-\). - For analog amplification applications we always add feedback to force the op amp to operate in the narrow linear region.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Inverting Amplifier – Circuit



Inverting amplifier



Input \(V_{\text{in}}\) through \(R_1\) to the inverting (−) input
Feedback resistor \(R_2\) from output to inverting node
Noninverting (+) input connected to ground
The inverting node is called the summing point or virtual ground


Point out: the inverting input is at a virtual ground (0 V) because ideal feedback keeps \(V_- = V_+ = 0\) V, but no current flows into the input, so this point is not actually connected to physical ground. This distinction is important when considering input and feedback currents.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Ideal Inverting Amplifier – Derivation
At the summing node (inverting input), apply KCL and the two golden rules.

Rule 1: No current into input → sum of resistor currents is zero.
Rule 2: \(V_- = V_+ = 0\) V (since \(V_+ = 0\)).

Currents:

Through \(R_1\): \(I_1 = \dfrac{V_{\text{in}} - 0}{R_1} = \dfrac{V_{\text{in}}}{R_1}\)
Through \(R_2\): \(I_2 = \dfrac{V_{\text{out}} - 0}{R_2} = \dfrac{V_{\text{out}}}{R_2}\)

KCL:
\[
I_1 + I_2 = 0 \tag{29}
\]
Substitute:
\[
\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R_1} + \frac{V_{\text{out}}}{R_2} = 0 \tag{30}
\]
Solve for \(V_{\text{out}}\):
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{R_2}{R_1} V_{\text{in}} \tag{31}
\]

Gain magnitude: \(\left|\dfrac{V_{\text{out}}}{V_{\text{in}}}\right| = \dfrac{R_2}{R_1}\)
180° phase inversion (sign change)







Note


The input impedance seen by \(V_{\text{in}}\) is approximately \(R_1\).




Relate this to a simple ECE example: use an inverting amplifier to scale a 0–5 V DAC output to a 0–10 V or −10 to +10 V range. Also point out that if \(R_2 < R_1\), the circuit attenuates; if \(R_2 > R_1\), it amplifies.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Interactive: Inverting Amplifier Gain Explorer

viewof R1_k = Inputs.range([1, 100], {step: 1, value: 10, label: "R1 (kΩ)"})
viewof R2_k = Inputs.range([1, 100], {step: 1, value: 47, label: "R2 (kΩ)"})






















Have students adjust the sliders and observe how the gain changes with the resistor ratio. Ask: If \(R_1 = 10\) kΩ and \(R_2 = 47\) kΩ, what’s the gain? What happens if we swap them? Reinforce that only the ratio matters for the gain.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: Nonideal Effects – Real Op Amp Behavior
text:
Nonideal Effects – Real Op Amp Behavior


Nonideal I/O characteristic



Nonideal I/O



Finite slope → finite open‑loop gain \(A\)
\(V_{\text{out}}\) saturates at \(\pm V_{\text{sat}}\)
Input offset voltage \(V_{\text{ios}}\) shifts the curve


Nonideal inverting amplifier model



Nonideal inverting amp



Finite input impedance \(z_{\text{in}}\)
Nonzero output impedance \(z_0\)
Finite gain \(A\)


Key definitions:

Open‑loop gain: \[
A = \left|\frac{\Delta V_{\text{out}}}{\Delta(V_2 - V_1)}\right|
    \approx \left|\frac{2 V_{\text{sat}}}{\Delta V}\right|
\]
Typical values:

\(V_{\text{sat}} \approx 10\) V
\(\Delta V \approx 100\,\mu\)V → \(A \approx 200{,}000\)



Explain that closed‑loop gain (with feedback) is mostly set by external resistors; the huge open‑loop gain makes the ideal rules very accurate. Mention that \(z_{\text{in}}\) is often in the MΩ range and \(z_0\) in tens of Ω, so loading effects are small in typical instrumentation applications.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: Nonideal Inverting Amplifier – Impact on Gain
text:
Nonideal Inverting Amplifier – Impact on Gain
Using the nonideal model (Figure 27b), we can derive:
\[
V_0 = -\frac{R_2}{R_1}\left(\frac{1}{1 - \mu}\right) V_{\text{in}} \tag{32}
\]
where
\[
\mu = \frac{\left(1 + \frac{z_0}{R_2}\right)\left(1 + \frac{R_2}{R_1} + \frac{R_2}{z_{\text{in}}}\right)}{A + \frac{z_0}{R_2}} \tag{33}
\]
If \(\mu \ll 1\), the gain reduces to the ideal form:
\[
V_0 \approx -\frac{R_2}{R_1} V_{\text{in}} \tag{31 revisited}
\]
Example parameter values:

\(A = 200{,}000\)
\(z_0 = 75\,\Omega\)
\(z_{\text{in}} = 2\,\text{M}\Omega\)
Gain \(R_2/R_1 = 100\), with \(R_2 = 100\,\text{k}\Omega\)

Then

\(\mu \approx 0.0005\)
Error in gain ≈ \(0.05\%\)







Tip


For most low‑frequency instrumentation designs, ideal op amp analysis is accurate enough, and we ignore \(\mu\) unless we push bandwidth or precision limits.




If time allows, walk through substituting the numerical values into (33) to show the smallness of \(\mu\). Connect this to why datasheets often say “closed‑loop gain accuracy ±0.1%” for typical resistor tolerances.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
4.2 Practical Op Amp Specifications
Important datasheet parameters beyond gain and impedances:

Input offset voltage \(V_{\text{ios}}\)

Voltage that must be applied between inputs to drive \(V_{\text{out}}\) to zero.

Input offset current

Difference between the two input bias currents that must flow to get \(V_{\text{out}} = 0\).

Input bias current

Average of the two input currents at zero output.

Slew rate (V/µs)

Maximum rate of change of the output voltage for a step input.

Unity‑gain frequency (gain‑bandwidth product)

Frequency where open‑loop gain drops to 1 (0 dB).








Warning


Offset voltages/currents matter most in:

Low‑level signals (mV, µV)
High‑gain DC amplifiers
Precision instrumentation (e.g., strain gauges, biomedical signals)





Use a quick numerical example: - If \(V_{\text{ios}} = 1\) mV and closed‑loop gain is 1000, the output offset can be ~1 V. Motivate the need for offset trimming and careful resistor selection.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: Practical Circuit: Op Amp with Power and Offset Trim
text:
Practical Circuit: Op Amp with Power and Offset Trim



Inverting amp with power and offset trim


Key practical details:

Bipolar supply: \(+V_s\) and \(-V_s\) (often ±12 V, ±15 V, etc.)
Optional offset trim pins to null input offset voltage using a trimmer resistor
Resistor at the noninverting input chosen to match effective resistance at inverting input to partially cancel input bias current errors


Explain how to do the offset‑null procedure:

Set \(V_{\text{in}} = 0\).
Measure \(V_{\text{out}}\).
Adjust the trim pot until \(V_{\text{out}} = 0\).

Once set, the offset is compensated unless the op amp is replaced or temperature changes drastically. Also mention that many modern zero‑drift op amps internally auto‑correct offset, reducing need for external trim.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: “Think mA and kΩ” – Output Current Limits
text:
“Think mA and kΩ” – Output Current Limits
Op amps have limited output current, typically ≈ 20 mA:

Total output current = load current + feedback current
Using very small resistors can demand too much current, causing:

Output voltage droop
Distortion
Potential device damage


Example 17 – Bad vs. Good Design
Desired: inverting amplifier with gain −4.5.

Design equation: \(-4.5 = -R_2/R_1\)

Impractical choice: \(R_1 = 1\,\Omega\), \(R_2 = 4.5\,\Omega\)

For \(V_{\text{in}} = 2\) V: \(V_{\text{out}} = -9\) V
\(I_2 = -9/4.5 = -2\) A (!) → far beyond op amp capability

Practical choice:

\(R_1 = 1\,\text{k}\Omega\), \(R_2 = 4.5\,\text{k}\Omega\)
Same gain, but feedback current is only 2 mA







Important


Rule of thumb: For general‑purpose op amps, choose resistor values such that currents are in the milliamp range and resistances in the kΩ range.




Ask students: If we used megaohm‑range resistors instead, what new problem might we encounter? (Answer: more thermal noise, higher sensitivity to bias currents and leakage.) So there is a tradeoff: avoid both extremely low and extremely high resistor values.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: 5. Op Amp Circuits in Instrumentation – Overview
text:
5. Op Amp Circuits in Instrumentation – Overview
Common building blocks:

Voltage follower (buffer) – unity gain, high input Z, low output Z.
Inverting amplifier – gain set by ratio \(R_2/R_1\), can attenuate or amplify.
Summing amplifier – weighted sum of multiple inputs.
Noninverting amplifier – high input Z, gain ≥ 1.
Differential and instrumentation amplifiers – measure differences, reject common mode.
Voltage‑to‑current (V–I) and current‑to‑voltage (I–V) converters – common in 4–20 mA loops.
Integrator and differentiator – time‑domain operations.
Nonlinear / linearization circuits – e.g., logarithmic amplifiers.

We will walk through each quickly with formulas and applications.

Emphasize that you don’t need to memorize every configuration; you should recognize patterns and know where to look up exact formulas. Also, instrumentation often chains these blocks: e.g., sensor → bridge → instrumentation amp → filter → V–I converter.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.1 Voltage Follower (Buffer)



Voltage follower



Output directly fed back to inverting input (−)
Input applied to noninverting input (+)

Ideal behavior:

\(V_{\text{out}} = V_{\text{in}}\) (unity gain)
Very high input impedance (often > 100 MΩ)
Very low output impedance (< 100 Ω)

Use case: Impedance transformer

Take a high‑impedance signal source (e.g., sensor, divider)
Deliver same voltage to a low‑impedance load without loading the sensor


Provide a real example: buffer the output of a thermistor divider or a potentiometer before feeding into an ADC with modest input impedance, to avoid changing the divider ratio. Mention that many ICs integrate a dedicated unity‑gain buffer op amp inside.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.2 Inverting Amplifier & Summing Amplifier
Recall:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{R_2}{R_1} V_{\text{in}} \tag{31}
\]
Summing Amplifier (two inputs example, Figure 31):



Summing amplifier


Transfer function:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\left[ \frac{R_2}{R_1} V_1 + \frac{R_2}{R_3} V_2 \right] \tag{34}
\]
Special cases:

\(R_1 = R_2 = R_3\) → \(V_{\text{out}} = -(V_1 + V_2)\) (inverted sum)
Other resistor choices provide weighted sums or averages







Note


Summing amplifiers are useful for:

Adding a DC offset (bias) to a signal
Mixing multiple sensor signals
Implementing simple DACs (weighted binary inputs)





Tie this to digital‑to‑analog conversion: A R‑2R ladder plus an op amp summing node can form a DAC. Also connect to Example 18 in the text (implementing \(V_{\text{out}} = 3.4V_{\text{in}} + 5\) using a summing amplifier followed by an inverter).

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example: Implementing ( V_{} = 3.4V_{} + 5 )
Strategy (as described in text):

Use a summing amplifier with two inputs: \(V_{\text{in}}\) and a fixed 5 V.

Gains chosen so output after the summing stage is \(-(3.4V_{\text{in}} + 5)\).

Follow with an inverting amplifier of gain −1 to remove the sign.




Circuit for Example 18


Resistor selection uses the same “mA and kΩ” philosophy.

Ask students to sketch numerical resistor values: - Suppose we choose \(R_{\text{f}} = 10\) kΩ. - For input 1 (signal), choose \(R_1\) so that \(R_{\text{f}}/R_1 = 3.4\). - For input 2 (5 V), choose \(R_3\) so that \(R_{\text{f}}/R_3 = 1\). Then add a unity‑gain inverting stage.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.3 Noninverting Amplifier



Noninverting amplifier



Input \(V_{\text{in}}\) applied to noninverting (+) input
Feedback and reference resistors \(R_2\) and \(R_1\) form a divider from \(V_{\text{out}}\) to ground
Summing point at inverting input has voltage \(V_S\)

KCL at node S and ideal equality \(V_- = V_+ = V_{\text{in}}\):
\[
\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R_1} + \frac{V_{\text{in}} - V_{\text{out}}}{R_2} = 0
\]
Solving:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = \left[1 + \frac{R_2}{R_1}\right] V_{\text{in}} \tag{35}
\]

Gain ≥ 1, cannot attenuate
Input impedance: very high (≈ op amp input Z)
Output impedance: low







Tip


Use noninverting amplifiers when you need high input impedance and positive gain (no phase inversion).




Connect to sensor interfaces: if your sensor is a weak voltage source, you typically buffer it (voltage follower) or amplify it using a noninverting stage. Also mention that to attenuate you must either use a passive divider or an inverting stage with \(R_2 < R_1\).

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example: Noninverting Gain of 42
Design a high‑impedance amplifier with voltage gain 42.
We use:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = \left[1 + \frac{R_2}{R_1}\right] V_{\text{in}}
\]
So
\[
42 = 1 + \frac{R_2}{R_1} \Rightarrow R_2 = 41 R_1
\]
Choose \(R_1 = 1\,\text{k}\Omega\), then \(R_2 = 41\,\text{k}\Omega\).

Input impedance ≈ op amp input impedance (>> MΩ).


You can ask students: could we instead choose \(R_1 = 2\) kΩ and \(R_2 = 82\) kΩ? Yes; the gain is still 42. Discuss tradeoffs in resistor sizes (noise, bias current effects).

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.4 Differential Amplifier – Core Concept
Goal: Amplify the difference between two voltages while rejecting any common‑mode voltage.
Ideal relationship:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = A (V_a - V_b) \tag{36}
\]
Common‑mode input voltage:
\[
V_{cm} = \frac{V_a + V_b}{2} \tag{37}
\]
Common‑mode rejection ratio (CMRR):
\[
\text{CMRR} = \frac{A}{A_{cm}} \tag{38}
\]
Common‑mode rejection (CMR) in dB:
\[
\text{CMR} = 20 \log_{10}(\text{CMRR}) \tag{39}
\]
Typical CMR for instrumentation amplifiers: 60–100 dB.






Important


High CMR is critical when your sensor signal is small but rides on a large common‑mode voltage (e.g., Wheatstone bridge outputs, biomedical electrodes, strain gauges).




Use simple numeric examples given in the text to show that a 0.1 V difference on 7.8 V vs. 7.7 V and −2.4 V vs. −2.5 V all yield the same differential output, while an ideal differential amplifier ignores the large common level.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Differential Amplifier Circuit



Differential amplifier



Requires two pairs of matched resistors: \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) on each side
Ideal transfer function (Appendix 6 derivation):

\[
V_{\text{out}} = \frac{R_2}{R_1} (V_2 - V_1) \tag{40}
\]
Notes:

Resistor matching quality strongly affects CMR.
Input impedances are not very high and not equal between inputs.
For instrumentation, we often add input buffers to make input impedance high and symmetric.


Discuss practical implementation: often use thin‑film resistor networks with tight ratio tolerances (0.01% or better) to achieve high CMR. Point out that with discrete 1% resistors, the achievable CMR can be limited by mismatch.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Instrumentation Amplifier – Buffered Differential Amp



Instrumentation amplifier with followers



Add voltage followers (buffers) before differential stage:

Greatly increases input impedance (ideal for sensor bridges).
Input loading becomes negligible.

Transfer function remains:

\[
V_{\text{out}} = \frac{R_2}{R_1} (V_2 - V_1) \tag{40 again}
\]
Disadvantage:

Changing gain requires changing both \(R_1\) resistors and keeping them matched.


Mention that many “3‑op‑amp instrumentation amplifier” ICs are based on this concept, but use a clever input stage to allow gain to be set by a single resistor. That configuration appears in Figure 37 later.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example 20 – Sensor 20–250 mV → 0–5 V
Sensor: \(V_{\text{in}}\) from 20 mV to 250 mV. Desired: \(V_{\text{out}}\) from 0 to 5 V, very high input impedance.
Model: linear relationship
\[
V_{\text{out}} = m V_{\text{in}} + V_0
\]
Use two points:
\[
\begin{aligned}
0 &= m(0.020) + V_0 \\
5 &= m(0.250) + V_0
\end{aligned}
\]
Solve:

\(V_0 = -0.434\) V
\(m = 21.7\)

So:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = 21.7 V_{\text{in}} - 0.434
\]
Alternative form:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = 21.7(V_{\text{in}} - 0.02)
\]
This looks like:

Differential amplifier with gain 21.7
Fixed 0.02 V offset applied to inverting input




Solution circuit Example 20



Point out how a zener diode plus resistor divider is used to create a stable 0.02 V reference, so supply variations don’t distort the mapping. Also highlight that an off‑the‑shelf instrumentation amplifier IC could implement this with fewer discrete parts.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: Instrumentation Amplifier with Single Gain Resistor
text:
Instrumentation Amplifier with Single Gain Resistor



3-op-amp instrumentation amplifier



Two input stages: noninverting amplifiers with shared gain‑setting resistor \(R_G\)
Third stage: differential amplifier with resistors \(R_2\) and \(R_3\)

Transfer function:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = \left(1 + \frac{2R_1}{R_G}\right)\left(\frac{R_3}{R_2}\right)(V_2 - V_1) \tag{41}
\]
Advantages:

Gain adjusted by single resistor \(R_G\)
High input impedance
High CMR, mainly dependent on matching of \(R_2\) and \(R_3\)

Many IC instrumentation amplifiers (e.g., AD620, INA128) use this topology.

Explain that IC manufacturers can laser‑trim \(R_2\) and \(R_3\) on‑chip to excellent matching, so the user just chooses \(R_G\) to set the desired gain without sacrificing CMR.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example 21 – Instrumenting a Wheatstone Bridge
Bridge (Figure 38): \(R_4\) varies from 100 Ω to 102 Ω.



Bridge


Bridge voltage: \(V_a - V_b = \Delta V\).
At \(R_4 = 102\,\Omega\) and \(R_1 = R_2 = R_3 = 100\,\Omega\), supply = 5 V:
\[
\Delta V = 5\left[\frac{100}{100+100} - \frac{102}{100+102}\right] = -24.75\text{ mV}
\]
Need: \(V_{\text{out}} = 0\) V at 100 Ω, \(V_{\text{out}} = 2.5\) V at 102 Ω.
So differential gain:
\[
A = \frac{2.5\text{ V}}{24.75\text{ mV}} \approx 101
\]
Using Eq. (41) with \(R_2 = R_3 = 1\text{ k}\Omega\), \(R_1 = 100\text{ k}\Omega\):
\[
101 = \left(1 + \frac{2 \cdot 100{,}000}{R_G}\right)\left(\frac{1000}{1000}\right)
\]
Solve for \(R_G\):
\[
R_G = 2000\,\Omega
\]
Polarity: connect bridge nodes such that \(V_b\) goes to the input that yields positive output as \(R_4\) increases.

Have students sanity‑check: a 2% change in resistance (100 → 102 Ω) yields only 24.75 mV at the bridge, which must be amplified by ≈ 100× to reach 2.5 V — a classic instrumentation amplifier application.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.5 Voltage‑to‑Current Converter



V-to-I converter


Used to drive 4–20 mA current loops from a voltage signal.
Transfer function (Appendix 6):
\[
I = -\frac{R_2}{R_1 R_3} V_{\text{in}} \tag{42}
\]
Condition on resistors:
\[
R_1(R_3 + R_5) = R_2 R_4 \tag{43}
\]
Maximum load resistance \(R_{ml}\) before saturation:
\[
R_{ml} = \frac{(R_4 + R_5)\left[\dfrac{V_{\text{sat}}}{I_m} - R_3\right]}{R_3 + R_4 + R_5} \tag{44}
\]

\(I_m\) is maximum desired output current
\(V_{\text{sat}}\) is op amp saturation voltage







Note


In instrumentation, current loops are robust to long cable runs and noise, so V–I converters are used at the transmitter end to convert local sensor voltage to a standardized current signal.




Emphasize that Eq. (44) shows \(R_{ml} < V_{\text{sat}}/I_m\) always, due to internal voltage drops.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example 22 – 0–1 V to 0–10 mA Converter
Requirements:

Input: 0–1 V signal
Output: 0–10 mA current
Op amp saturation: ±10 V

Strategy:

The V–I converter inverts (negative sign in Eq. 42), so we first invert the 0–1 V to 0 to −1 V with a simple inverting amplifier.
Choose \(R_1 = R_2\) in the V–I converter:
Then Eq. (42) becomes: \[
I = -\frac{R_2}{R_1 R_3}V_{\text{in}} = -\frac{1}{R_3}V_{\text{in}}
\]
For 10 mA at 1 V (actually −1 V at the converter input):
\[
R_3 = \frac{1\text{ V}}{10\text{ mA}} = 100\,\Omega
\]
Choose \(R_5 = 0\) so Eq. (43) simplifies to \(R_1 R_3 = R_2 R_4\). With \(R_1=R_2\), we get \(R_3 = R_4 = 100\,\Omega\).
Maximum load resistance (Eq. 44):
\[
R_{ml} = 100\left[\frac{10\text{ V}}{10\text{ mA}} - 100\right] / 200 = 450\,\Omega
\]

So the loop can drive up to 10 mA into a 450 Ω load.

Ask: what happens if the cable and receiver resistance exceed 450 Ω? The op amp will saturate before delivering full 10 mA, causing a nonlinear transfer and limiting measurement range.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.6 Current‑to‑Voltage Converter



I-to-V converter


At the receiving end of a current loop, convert current back to a voltage:

Sensor loop current \(I\) flows into the summing node through \(R\).
Op amp adjusts \(V_{\text{out}}\) to keep input node at virtual ground.

Transfer function:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -I R \tag{45}
\]

Very linear as long as op amp does not saturate
Choose \(R\) so that max current yields desired output range


Give a simple design: for 4–20 mA loop and required 1–5 V output, choose \(R\) such that: - 4 mA → 1 V, 20 mA → 5 V → \(R = 5\text{ V}/20\text{ mA} = 250\,\Omega\). Then 4 mA yields 1 V automatically.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.7 Integrator



Integrator



Input resistor \(R\)
Feedback capacitor \(C\)

Summing node equation (ideal op amp):
\[
\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R} + C\frac{dV_{\text{out}}}{dt} = 0 \tag{46}
\]
Integrate both sides:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{1}{RC} \int V_{\text{in}}\,dt \tag{47}
\]
If \(V_{\text{in}}\) is a constant \(K\):
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{K}{RC} t \tag{48}
\]
→ Ideal ramp generator with slope \(-K/(RC)\).






Caution


In practice, integrators need reset/clamp circuits and often a resistor in parallel with \(C\) to prevent drift and saturation from DC offsets.




Mention uses: numerical integration of accelerometer signals to get velocity, implementing analog filters, ramp generators in timing circuits.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Example 23 – 10 V/ms Ramp
Goal: ramp increasing at 10 V/ms.
Desired:
\[
\frac{dV_{\text{out}}}{dt} = 10\text{ V/ms}
\]
Use integrator:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{RC} t
\]
Let \(RC = 1\) ms and \(V_{\text{in}} = -10\) V. Then:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -\frac{-10}{1\text{ ms}} t = 10\frac{\text{V}}{\text{ms}}t
\]
Example component choices:

\(R = 1\,\text{k}\Omega\), \(C = 1\,\mu\text{F}\) → \(RC = 1\) ms


Stress that in practice the ramp cannot grow forever; the op amp saturates at some ±\(V_{\text{sat}}\). A reset (switching \(C\) to discharge) is often used.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.8 Differentiator



Differentiator



Capacitor in series at input, resistor in feedback

Summing node equation:
\[
C\frac{dV_{\text{in}}}{dt} + \frac{V_{\text{out}}}{R} = 0 \tag{49}
\]
Solve for \(V_{\text{out}}\):
\[
V_{\text{out}} = -RC\frac{dV_{\text{in}}}{dt} \tag{50}
\]
So output is proportional to the time derivative of \(V_{\text{in}}\).






Warning


Real differentiators tend to be noisy and unstable: they amplify high‑frequency noise and any fast transients. They are typically used only as part of more complex, bandwidth‑limited circuits.




Explain that in practice we use “practical differentiator” circuits that add series/parallel resistors and capacitors to limit gain at high frequency, essentially implementing a band‑limited differentiator.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
5.9 Op Amp Linearization & Nonlinear Circuits
Idea: place a nonlinear element in the feedback loop of an op amp.



Nonlinear amplifier


Summing point equation:
\[
\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R} + I(V_{\text{out}}) = 0 \tag{51}
\]
Solve for \(V_{\text{out}}\):
\[
V_{\text{out}} = G\left(\frac{V_{\text{in}}}{R}\right) \tag{52}
\]
Where \(G\) is related to the inverse of \(I(V_{\text{out}})\).
Example: diode in feedback → logarithmic amplifier.



Diode feedback log amp


Diode equation:
\[
I(V_{\text{out}}) = I_0 \exp(\alpha V_{\text{out}}) \tag{53}
\]
Substituting and inverting:
\[
V_{\text{out}} = \frac{1}{\alpha}\ln(V_{\text{in}}) - \frac{1}{\alpha}\ln(I_0 R) \tag{54}
\]
→ Output is logarithmic in input.

Mention uses of log amps: - Expanding dynamic range (e.g., audio compression, power meters) - Converting multiplication/division to addition/subtraction in analog computers. Linearization: by appropriately choosing or designing nonlinear feedback, you can make a nonlinear sensor’s output more nearly linear.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: 6. Design Guidelines for Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
6. Design Guidelines for Analog Signal Conditioning



Measurement & S/C model


General workflow:

Define the measurement objective
Select the sensor (if not fixed)
Design the analog S/C block
Check accuracy, loading, noise, and practical constraints

We’ll summarize each step as a design checklist.

Encourage students to explicitly write each of these items when given a design problem; it clarifies assumptions and avoids hidden requirements.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Step 1 – Define the Measurement Objective

Parameter

What are we measuring? Temperature, pressure, flow, position, voltage, current…

Range

Min/max of the physical variable: e.g., 100–200 °C, 45–85 psi.

Accuracy

Required error bounds: e.g., ±5% full scale (FS), ±3% of reading.

Linearity

Must the mapping from parameter to output be linear?

Noise environment

Expected interference (EMI), frequency content, and noise levels.








Tip


Clearly stating these before drawing circuits avoids under‑ or over‑design (e.g., using an ultra‑precision amp when 5% error is acceptable).




Give a quick example: - “Measure water level between 0.5–2.0 m with ±1 cm accuracy; output 1–5 V; environment: industrial plant with motor noise.” From this, we know we need good EMI immunity, likely shielded cables and filtering.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
text:
Step 2 – Understand / Select the Sensor
If the sensor is given, document its characteristics; if not, choose an appropriate one.

Output parameter

Does the sensor produce resistance, voltage, current, frequency, etc.?

Transfer function

Relationship between input (physical) and output (electrical).
Linear? Nonlinear? Given by equation or table?

Time response

First‑order time constant, 2nd‑order dynamics, bandwidth.

Range

Range of sensor output over measurement range.

Power limits

Max dissipation, max current/voltage, self‑heating constraints.



Highlight that many sensor datasheets specify maximum excitation current or power; exceeding that can change the reading (self‑heating) or permanently damage the sensor.

title: Operational Amplifiers in Instrumentation
section: Step 3 – Design the Analog Signal Conditioning
text:
Step 3 – Design the Analog Signal Conditioning

Desired output parameter

Usually a voltage for ADCs (e.g., 0–5 V, ±10 V).
Sometimes current (4–20 mA) or frequency.

Output range

Ensure mapping covers full ADC input range for better resolution.

Input impedance of S/C

Must not excessively load sensor or bridge.

Output impedance of S/C

Must be low enough for the next stage (ADC, recorder, actuator driver).








Note


For voltage‑output sensors, high input impedance is often crucial. For bridge‑based sensors, design excitation and bridge resistances to respect sensor power limits and linearity.




Reinforce the “develop an equation first” approach: Write \(V_{\text{out}} = m (\text{sensor variable}) + V_0\), then implement it with op amp blocks.
